newsitem.title: UK: GEC freed from Siemens defence unit buy ban.
newsitem.headline: GEC freed from Siemens defence unit buy ban.

text.p: Margaret Beckett, president of Britain's Board of Trade, said on Friday she had freed General Electric Co Plc from its undertakings not to acquire any interest in or influence over the management of enterprises within Siemens AG's defence units.
GEC is currently on the short list of bidders to buy Siemens Plessey, the German engineering group's defence business which is up for sale.
These undertakings were first given in 1989, under the Fair Trading Act and followed advice by the competition watchdog the Office of Fair Trading.
The undertakings had related to Plessey Radar and Defence Systems businesses as well as the Plessey Traffic Control unit.

Commenting on her decision, Beckett said "I have decided that circumstances in the defence industry and air traffic control have changed sufficiently since the MMC made its report, such that it is no longer appropriate to maintain restrictions on GEC beyond the normal consideration to which they would be subject under competition legislation."

She concluded "My decision to release GEC is therefore without prejudice to any consideration by the relevant competition authorities, whether UK and European, of any possible future acquisition involving these businesses."
